title: HW1
description: A short description of the post.
contents:
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = FALSE)

vac_tn <- c(52.01,39.84,33.42,5.8,7.29,4.73,4.29,0.55)
pop <- c(83.78,60.46,46.75,10.42,10.2,8.65,5.79,0.89)
vac_sh <- vac_tn/pop
perc_vac_sh <- vac_sh*100
perc_vac_sh > 70


[1] FALSE FALSE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE FALSE

Assuming that each vaccine dose provides full immunity and therefore is administered to different individuals, I examined the vaccination rates of 8 countries (Germany, Italy, Spain, Greece, Portugal, Switzerland, Denmark, Cypurs). I found that only in 3 cases (Spain, Portugal,Denmark) the herd immunity threshold of 70% has been reached!

title: Post 1 HMWK 1
description: This is my post for the first homework
contents:
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = FALSE)
vector <- c(1,2,3,4,5)
new_vector <- c(3,5,1,1,2)
avg_vector <- (vector + new_vector)/2
perc_vector <- avg_vector/5
final_vector <- perc_vector*100



First I input two vectors: vector = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and new_vector = 3, 5, 1, 1, 2 Then I take the average of these two vectors creating avg_vector = 2, 3.5, 2, 2.5, 3.5 Then I divide the average of the vectors by 5 (perc_vector = 0.4, 0.7, 0.4, 0.5, 0.7) and finally I multiple the vector by 100 (final_vector = 40, 70, 40, 50, 70).

title: Hello World
description: Marina's first attempt at using distill
contents:
Hi folks! My name is Marina. I will now try to make R do something
What does the UCB Admissions dataset look like?

     Admit Gender Dept Freq
1 Admitted   Male    A  512
2 Rejected   Male    A  313
3 Admitted Female    A   89
4 Rejected Female    A   19
5 Admitted   Male    B  353
6 Rejected   Male    B  207

How many departments are in the dataset?


A B C D E F 
4 4 4 4 4 4 

How many people were admitted across all departments?

[1] "The sum of all admits is 1755"

title: Still Learning the GitHib Workflow
contents:
Using Markdown is fun!
I learned a lot this summer — Markdown is your friend, as are flexdashboard and Stack Overflow.
Also, always keep in mind that social scientists understand data and data management just as well (if not better) than the computer scientists.

title: Welcome to DACSS 601
contents: Welcome to the Data Analytics and Computational Social Science Programs’ Orientation 2021 session of DACSS 601 Foundations of Data Science. This blog will feature the work of our incoming M.S. students taking the class, as well as PhD students in the College of Behavioral and Social Sciences who have decided to participate through “R Bootcamp”.
